title: Wednesday, 3rd October 2018

annotations.prefLabel: Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings PLC

bodyHTML:
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Hello, good morning, etc.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
nightingale20201 morning....
BE11:09am

Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing. Me again. BE again.

Soundbuy Morning
BE11:10am

Be again. All that old misery. Once wasn't enough for you.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

Anyway, where to start?

nightingale20201 could you have a look at TESCO...is that a share price overreaction?
Soundbuy ITV - took their time.............
PBateman Morning all
Manxish Morning each
BE11:10am

Stupid overpriced floats? Seems as good a place as any.

Kiwi-juice Aston Martin!
nightingale20201 before we turn to the Tory Leadership Conference, thanks
BE11:11am

Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings trading at £18 live.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Having priced towards the bottom of the range at £19.

BE11:12am

To remind, range was £17.50 to £22.50.

BE11:12am

And they tried every damn trick in the book(runner) to get this away.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Such as this one, midway through yesterday .....

BE11:13am

FERRARI IS SAID TO HAVE MULLED BUYING ASTON MARTIN IN 2015

Otter Hello friends
Forester Nice cars, nice brand but a business that have been bust 7 times.....not for me thanks!
BE11:13am

Uh .... huh. Sure sure.

Finlay Is this that 'hubris' deal we look back on?
Imperial Goldsmith That one was lol
FATDAZ @Nightingale an -8% fall in the price based on a 3% miss on operating profits sounds extreme to me but there may be something else i haven't seen
11:14 am
BE11:15am

A quick reminder of the Aston numbers ......

BE11:15am

This year it'll do between 6,200 and 6,400 units

FATDAZ Wasn't there recent talk that Ferrari was struggling and company upmwith schemes to build $5 million dollar cars to make ends meet
Kiwi-juice Amazon comment? If this is a pay increase of say $3 per hour to all their staff, that may cost then $3bn extra or 17% of the 2019 expected EBIT. A massive earnings cut
BE11:16am

On an adjusted EBIT margin of ~13%

pancakes or waffles to all their staff?
11:17 am
BE11:17am

That goes up to 7,300 next year, 9,800 by 2020 and 14,000 in the medium term, with management also targeting greater than 20% margin by then.

andyalan10 I have a complaint, yesterday afternoon I read half of a months old Markets Live due to an autocompleted URL when I was looking for yesterday's edition. I assumed it was current because it started at 11:09!
FATDAZ @kiwi staff may have to go out and buy roller skates to improve efficiency as result :)
BE11:17am

Will any of this happen? Of course it won't!

Excel Developer @Kiwi-juice, which quarter earnings will that be reported in please?
Imperial Goldsmith ......But Lazard and JPM go home happy
BE11:18am

Why on earth would you expect a company that's been going since 1913 to suddenly function better simply because its previous backers have cashed out?

cheeckychappy @BE - so cynical...
Excel Developer @Kiwi-juice: are talking 2019 Q1. I was wondering about tariffs hitting other US stocks in that earnings season. Put that next to a disappointing 2018 Q4 USA GDP print on Jan 25th I think SP500 will struggle from January onwards next year.
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Let me get the income statement .....

BE11:19am

BE11:20am

And the balance sheet.

Lawro Tory MP James Duddridge has written to the chairman of the Conservative 1922 committee calling for a change of leader, saying : "I write this with heavy heart however we now need a proper leadership election and to move on."
Tom Dalgleish Does the younger generation even know what James Bond was and what car he allegedly drove?
11:20 am
BE11:21am

BE11:21am

Numbers via Crispidea.

BE11:22am

Nearly £1bn of debt against net income sub £80m. Sure, why not.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Good luck to all holders.

undefined
BE11:23am

Okay, so Tesco.

cracklenpop @FATDAZ@FATDAZ Big margin miss at Tesco - international operating margins at 2.9% vs 3.5% consensus, UK came in at 2.66% vs 2.73%.
11:22 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 214.55, down 20.65 (-8.78%), High: 225.10, Low: 214.00, Volume: 53.66m
BE11:23am

It's a miss. A massive miss.

FATDAZ @Crackle n pop thanks that explains a lot
BE11:23am

Half-year profit's about 6% below consensus, though that's a tad deceptive .....

11:23 am
BE11:23am

.... because a lot of that's an £8m property loss

cloudy Current liabilities for 2015 don't add up Bryce (221.8).
BE11:24am

Underlying, it's a couple for things. Firstly, Asia.

BE11:25am

Which is needing a lot more price investment and like-for-likes are going south quite sharply.

cracklenpop @Lawro Duddridge was on the radio this morning saying he'd listen to May's speech before deciding to write his letter. He's obviously seen a draft.
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Secondly, Booker.

BE11:25am

Where margins have also gone south.

Excel Developer On 1922 letters Graham Brady, says MPs go on telly and lie about having written them.
BE11:26am

Core Tesco is fine. The UK, the bank, etc. All in line. It's the fringe stuff that's sinking group performance.

Excel Developer (Graham Brady is to whom these letters are addressed)
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Here's Goldman.

FATDAZ sorry early bath today bye
Excel Developer @fatdaz: congrats on forex awards.
BE11:28am

Tesco (Buy) reported 1H19 Group EBIT growth (including Booker) of +24% yoy to £933mn, -4.3%/-4.6% below GSe/Vuma consensus, driven by Asia c.25% below expectations. 2Q19 UK ex-fuel LFL sales growth was a positive surprise at +2.5% vs GSe/cons at +1.8%/+2.0%, with Booker +15.1% ahead of GSe/cons at +14.3%/+13.1%. On the EBIT side, the c.£40mn miss was driven by c.£30mn in Asia and c.£10mn at Booker (we believe driven by a higher proportion of low margin tobacco and drinks in the mix than we had forecast), with the underlying UK business in line with our expectations. Management reiterated margin targets and synergy guidance; however we would expect LSD FY EBIT consensus downgrades driven by the Asia miss and where investments are expected to continue in 2H19.

BE11:28am

Asia 1H19 EBIT down 29%!

11:28 am
BE11:28am

-137bps to 4.2%!

BE11:29am

Tesco called out the combined impact of sales deleverage, price investment and renegotiation of promotional investment. They expect this impact to continue in 2H19 as they maintain investment in price in a competitive market.

Excel Developer Graham Brady on eurosceptics inflating 1922 numbers, https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/eurosceptic-mps-are-accused-of-inflating-leadership-threat-to-may-c9pmpbrpx paywalled
BE11:30am

So, that's the knock on effect. Asia. Added to that the cash, which was weak even before the exceptionals.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Kepler:

BE11:30am

Retail operating cash flow adjusted by the one-time impact of the bankruptcy of Palmer and Harvey increased by 11%, as changes in working capital normalised at around GBP110m (vs. GBP244m in H1 2017-18) and
exceptional cash items declined. Retail FCF ex P&H disruption declined by 8%, or by 17% excluding all exceptionals.

Forester Rumour has it that in the next Bond film, he will get an Uber back to the hotel with the girl before ordering something on JustEat!
Excel Developer @Forester: AirBnB surely?
BE11:31am

Okay, so this is interesting ...... The Asia performance ........

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Some folk seem to be linking it to Thailand, where new government welfare cards can't be redeemed in the big grocers.

Tom Dalgleish What's a Russian agent doing driving an Uber?
BE11:32am

Haven't heard the Tesco conference call. But if that's even part of the reason, it's a good story.

undefined
Excel Developer Post Brexit, goodbye inward Japanese investment, https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-03/japan-waves-goodbye-to-u-k-as-gateway-to-europe-post-brexit
nightingale20201 fyi, the non redeemable welfare cards in thai was referenced in TSCO's statement
Excel Developer If inward investment collapses doesn't this put a ton of pressure on Sterling.
11:34 am
BE11:34am

What else?

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 161.05, up 4.65 (+2.97%), High: 165.80, Low: 156.00, Volume: 7.43m
Tom Dalgleish I was musing today that the growth of solar arrays to generate electricity, which is huge in sunny climes like these, will kill off Aggreko
BE11:35am

(@nightingale20201: was it? Missed that. Ta.)

11:35 am
BE11:35am

They're out of the Endemol auction with a somewhat sniffy statement.

BE11:36am

In light of continued press speculation, ITV confirms that it has no current intention of making a bid for Endemol Shine Group.

Maudise @Excel, yes and on top of that a short term crisis as capital reallocates causing not only a demand deficit, but a supply glut.
BE11:36am

In light of what continued press speculation?

Excel Developer @Maudise: supply glut of what? Aggregate supply? I think I heard Carney call Brexit a supply shock but a negative one, i.e. a fall in supply.
graunch Did we like yesterday's 2008 telling on the beeb last night?
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Last reports I think were the weekend of September 22, and were downstory references in the Birmingham Mail and Sunday Independent.

Sails @Tom Dalgelish solar arrays aren't really there yet as a compact, powerful & portable power source comparable to a fossil fuel generator are they?
BE11:39am

Before that you're looking back to September 19, following a Sunday Times story.

Excel Developer @maudise: From the FT, https://www.ft.com/content/3d0351e1-8c9e-39ba-b9b5-e599d604e4cf "Carney says it's a large supply shock, which is relatively unusual."
BE11:40am

If that's the level of continuing press speculation that deserves a statement from ITV, that's useful to know. Because in the past they've been much less forthcoming with their statements ......

11:39 am
Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 414.20, up 1.4 (+0.34%), High: 415.00, Low: 411.40, Volume: 51.63k
CrowK "Government-issued welfare cards continue to impact sales in Thailand by c.(2)%"Results in £2bn off market cap?
Maudise Supply of GBP as people liquidate assets in UK to reallocate to another country causing people to translate GBP illiquid assets into EURI'll give it a read.
Maudise all negative for Sterling though to be clear.
Excel Developer @maudise: ah yeah supply of sterling, got ya. cheers.
BE11:41am

....... Anyway, they're not going to chuck £2bn or so at a not too great production studio that's changed ownership many times already.

BE11:41am

So, rally.

11:41 am
undefined
GBKrona @BE - any analyst comment on Funding Circle please? Down over 20% on 1st day
BE11:42am

@GBKrona, sellside are still in IPO blackout on Funding Circle, so no.

Funding Circle Holdings PLC (FCH:LSE): Last: 383.05, up 19.05 (+5.23%), High: 390.00, Low: 339.90, Volume: 1.31m
chad_john Greencore up 6%...
11:43 am
BE11:43am

All I can do is direct you to this old Kadhim post: https://ftalphavil...ng-funding-circle/

undefined
GBKrona thanks @BE - I guess also yesterday was a bum day to have a finance based IPO - most financials were at medium term lows
BE11:47am

What else we got? Not a great deal today .......

11:47 am
BE11:47am

I know as much as you about Greencore, and possibly less.

Greencore Group PLC (GNC:LSE): Last: 195.95, up 10.95 (+5.92%), High: 197.00, Low: 184.15, Volume: 2.73m
A. M. Anything on Shell's Canadian LNG (beyond Lex's take)?
BE11:49am

Put it on Tesco's in-line UK figures, if you like, given Tesco's about 5% of revenue. Or put it on the grift about potential interest that's been floating around for what must be at least a year. I know nothing.

Flaneur On Aston Martin - sporty, high class product thats always 1 gen behind its rivals. Bought on sentiment. Cant believe its floating ....said the actress to the bishop...
nichoman anything on schroders / lloyds
A. M. @Flaneur: the vertu of cars, then?
11:50 am
undefined
Soundbuy Hello..............?
Soundbuy Ah.....................
BE11:53am

Schroders? Um, nope. Nor Lloyds. They came back yesterday with the peer group and they're up a bit today with the peer group. I'd like to provide something else of consequence here but we can only work with what we have.

nichoman giant scottish widows mandate is the link!
BE11:54am

On Amazon ...... which I think was mentioned earlier ......

11:54 am
BE11:54am

There's the simple mechanical effect of paying people more.

BE11:54am

Amazon announced plans to increase the minimum wage for all US employees to $15/hour starting November 1st. Assuming 400k global employees impacted and average wage increase of around $2.50/hr, we est $2.1bn incremental opex in '19E. Lowering estimates, but right move for employees, with potential political and regulatory benefits; reiterate Buy.

BE11:55am

That's Merrill.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

(@Nichoman: ah! this story. https://www.ft.com...-ba8f-ee390057b8c9 ... I totally forgot about it, sorry.)

BE11:56am

And this is Jefferies.

BE11:56am

We estimate AMZN raising the minimum wage of its US and UK employees would cost the Co ~$1.5B/year and dilute EPS by 8% in CY19. These ests, however, assume all other costs remain constant, which we think is unlikely. Strategic and operational benefits, including 1) proper staffing levels for the critical holiday season, 2) cost pressure on competitors, and 3) some diffusion of
regulatory pressure on AMZN, should offset a good portion of the incremental cost.

Excel Developer Theresa May dancing on stage entrance, putting a brave face on it, I see.
11:57 am
BE11:57am

We believe the wage raise was a smart move by AMZN especially given the labor shortage in retail. Securing proper staffing levels (which we believe the raise would achieve) right before the critical holiday season could ensure AMZN does not have to incur additional fulfillment costs. Spikes in demand at a time of tight logistics capacity have caused the Co problems in the past.

BE11:58am

Strategic benefits: raising the minimum wage at AMZN is expected to have a ripple effect through retail, putting pressure on competitors to raise their wages (and costs) too. Given the high automation levels at AMZN fulfillment centers, the impact of a wage raise should be much more pronounced at its brick-and-mortar competitors.
Political benefits: by raising the minimum wage, AMZN should be able to placate political pressure about its labor practices (claims the Co is not paying adequate wages to employees) and simultaneously raise the question about pay practices at other retailers, which tend to pay even less. With this move, the Co could possibly be able to turn unwanted political attention to other major US retailers and away from itself.

Excel Developer @BE: thanks for SP500 consitutent grey! I'd like to vote to see more of that. FTSE100 is rubbish.
BE11:59am

Paying workers more results in happier workers. It's a radical and potentially dangerous concept but I'm glad to see it surfacing, even at the sunset stage of western capitalism.

Frances Anything on Victrex?
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Goldman, though. Trust Goldman .....

Bluesky21 Parallels to be drawn with Henry Ford raising wages for his workers?
BE12:00pm

[O]ur EBITDA estimates over the next 3 years decline by approximately 5% on average per year. With Amazon’s margins having surprised to the upside in recent quarters on fulfillment efficiencies, a growing ad business, and Prime rate increases, we would expect these drivers to fund the wage increases vs. passing it through to consumers via higher prices. We remain Buy rated (on CL) as our 12-month price target goes to $2,250 from $2,300 to reflect these changes.

Sails Hard to believe Jeff Bozos has had some Damascene conversion; more likely he's following Henry Ford who paid his workers reasonably well 'so they can buy one of my cars'
Sails Exactly @Bluesky :-)
Blank canvas Gin bottles uncorked, noonday gun already fired. Thanks for everything today.
BE12:01pm

Yeah, they can just pay more by charging more. Thanks. Good thinking.

12:01 pm
undefined
Bluesky21 @ sails - thanks. Reading biographies on Ford, though, it seems like he was more interested in stemming very high staff turnover
BE12:02pm

@Frances, Victrex is a Merrill downgrade.

Pharma You get the staff you pay for. Pay peanuts, and you tend to get monkeys.
BE12:02pm

Summarised here: https://www.ft.com...-ba8f-ee390057b8c9

GBKrona thanks @BE / ROTR, hasta manana
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Along with a not much else yet, because I was busy on other stuff this morning. Being busy also takes the blame for today's session being rubbish, and apologies for that.

BE12:04pm

We got through it, though. Together.

BE12:04pm

Thanks for the comments. Back tomorrow, one assumes.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Afternoon all.

Excel Developer @BE: no worries mate, keep dropping SP500 grey and you'll do fine. Cheers, bye
Frances Thank you!
